description: From Middle English way, wey, from Old English weġ, from Proto-West Germanic *weg, from Proto-Germanic *wegaz, from Proto-Indo-European *weǵʰ-. Doublet of voe and possibly via.

definitionGroups.group: (heading) To do with a place or places.

entries.meaning: A road, a direction, a (physical or conceptual) path from one place to another.
examples: Do you know the way to the airport?  Come this way and I'll show you a shortcut.  It's a long way from here.

entries.meaning: A means to enter or leave a place.
examples: We got into the cinema through the back way.
If you're ever 'round this way, come over and visit me.

entries.meaning: A method or manner of doing something; a mannerism.
examples: You're going about it the wrong way.  He's known for his quirky ways.  I don't like the way she looks at me.
When I returned home, I found my house and belongings in a most terrible way.

entries.meaning: Possibility (usually in the phrases 'any way' and 'no way').
examples: There's no way I'm going to clean up after you.

entries.meaning: Determined course; resolved mode of action or conduct.
examples: My little sister always whines until she gets her way.

entries.meaning: (Germanic paganism) A tradition within the modern pagan faith of Heathenry, dedication to a specific deity or craft, Way of wyrd, Way of runes, Way of Thor etc.

examples: Ten minutes into the run Tang slowed, Welch calling out her speed as she lost way.

entries.meaning: A degree, an amount, a sense.
examples: In a significant way, crocodiles and alligators are similar.

entries.meaning: (US, As the head of an interjectory clause, followed by an infinitive starting with “to”) Acknowledges that a task has been done well, chiefly in expressions of sarcastic congratulation.
examples: Way to ruin the moment, guys.

entries.meaning: (plural only) The timbers of shipyard stocks that slope into the water and along which a ship or large boat is launched.
(plural only) The longitudinal guiding surfaces on the bed of a planer, lathe, etc. along which a table or carriage moves.

verbs.description: way (third-person singular simple present ways, present participle waying, simple past and past participle wayed)

examples: on a time as they together way'd, / He made him open chalenge […] .

entries.meaning: (informal, with comparative or modified adjective) Much.
examples: I'm way too tired to do that.
I'm a way better singer than Emma.
String theory is way cool, except for the math.
I used to live way over there.
The farmhouse is way down the bottom of the hill.

description: From the sound it represents, by analogy with other (velar) letters such as kay and gay.

entries.meaning: The letter for the w sound in Pitman shorthand.
